frqParts.text: Read each question carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. Students design an experiment using blocks of adjustable mass to investigate friction using the setup shown. Block <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> of initial mass <math alttext="0.44 kilogram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.44</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is placed on a rough horizontal surface and connected by a string to block <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> of initial mass <math alttext="0.20 kilogram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.20</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The string extends over a pulley that has negligible mass and friction. (a) Calculate the minimum value of the coefficient of static friction <math alttext="mu sub S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> that would keep the two-block system at rest.

The coefficient of friction is such that when block <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is released from rest, block <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> travels across the surface. The acceleration <math alttext="a" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of each block is recorded with motion detectors <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, as shown in the figure. The data for the motion detectors as functions of time <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are shown on the graphs. For each motion detector, the positive direction is away from the detector. (b) On the dots below, which represent the blocks, draw and label the forces (not components) that act on each block. Each force must be represented by a distinct arrow starting on, and pointing away from, the dot.

(c) Calculate the coefficient of kinetic friction <math alttext="mu sub k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> between block <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and the table.

(d) Careful measurements determine that the coefficient of kinetic friction is larger than the value calculated in part (c). Does the following explanation sufficiently account for the observed discrepancy? “The horizontal table was not perfectly level before the experiment was conducted. The observed difference in the angle accounts for the difference in the expected and calculated values of <math alttext="mu sub k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.” Yes No Justify your answer.

The experiment is moved to a surface with negligible friction and run for eight trials. In each trial, the masses <math alttext="m sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="m sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> are varied, while the total mass <math alttext="m sub 1 plus m sub 2, equals 0.64 kilogram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>0.64</mn><mtext> </mtext><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> remains constant. The data for the acceleration <math alttext="a" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>a</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of block <math overflow="scroll"> <mn>1</mn> </math> as a function of <math alttext="m sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> are shown on the graph below. (e) i. Draw a best-fit line for the data points.
ii. Using the straight line, calculate an experimental value for the acceleration due to gravity <math alttext="g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(f) The students lift the left end of the surface so that the surface is inclined at an angle below the horizontal, and the experiment for <math alttext="m sub 2, equals 0.20 kilogram" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0.20</mn><mtext> kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is repeated. Would the acceleration of the system be greater than, less than or equal to the acceleration of the system in the original experiment? _____ Greater than _____ Less than _____ Equal to Justify your claim.
